dialogue: How wonderful it is to finally make your acquaintance!
I admit there was a period of time when we thought he had made you up! Isn't it fascinating to meet the significant others of great artists and thinkers?
Thank you for taking care of my Laszlo.

As persons of unique privilege, I have always thought that it is our duty to nurture the defining talents of our epoch. I possess no such talent whatsoever! Truth be told, I am terribly emulous of individuals like him.
That mustn't be true, Mr. Van Buren. It seems you've done quite all right for yourself.
Oh, that's fine, just fine. Feel free to call me Elizabeth if you prefer it.
Your English is impressive.
Thank you. I attended University in England!
Where?
Oxford to study English. I returned home for Communications.
Did you do anything with it?
Oh yes. I wrote for a popular national paper at home; Magyar Nemzet.
A journalist?
Where are you two headed?
We're going into town.
Which town is that? We've got several nearby, you know!
Philadelphia. To visit family.
Ah, yes. The American cousin! The city then! Us, as well.
Yes, the city.
Well, don't just stand there. Let us give you and your Auntie a lift.
I have a friend in New York, a newspaper man. He's always on the lookout for new talent. Shall I mention you to him?
Well, yes, of course. That is very kind of you, Mr. Van Buren.
Would that mean I would have to work out of New York?
In the beginning, perhaps... But you haven't got the job yet so let's not get ahead of ourselves.
No, no, of course not. I did not mean it to be presumptuous!
The road is rough and the engine, loud.
What's that?
I did not mean it to be presumptuous!
In any event, you could commute there with me at the start. I'm there Monday to Friday.
Well, sure, that could be fine. I'd have to speak with Laszlo though.
When we break ground, he will have his hands full, I can assure you! VAN BUREN's intent is enigmatic.
I enjoy showing friends around Manhattan. You mustn't have seen much on your way in.
The Penn Station Terminal was very nice.
-a pity that it's become so full of tramps hassling women and children with their arms outstretched. They line up and extend from the walls as if integral to its very foundation like-
-like a haunted wall mural!
Ah, perhaps that is why I felt so at home. I'm a former bag lady myself who does also enjoy the work of the Dutch masters.
`Earthly Delights!' You pictured it just as I meant it. Clever, clever.
"Integral to its foundation." You sound like my husband. Although a mural's decorative; nothing to do with the foundation.
Where did you get your passion for architecture?
Oh, we've done buildings before but I'd hardly call them artistic. I suppose it was because the cellar was full.
Pardon?
I collect books, butterflies, and such. Above all though, Portuguese Madeira. I take it every night after supper.

I did the maths and if I were to uncork a bottle seven days a week for the next thirty years - the maximum of my life expectancy - I shouldn't need more than ten thousand altogether. So once the cellar was full, it was time I set about in a new direction. Out of the cellar and into the sky.
If you drink a bottle of Madeira every day, I shouldn't think you'd last thirty years.
I always keep good company.
I'm proud of you. Make love to me tonight.
All right everyone! On three...
Mr. T-oth, it's time we return to our quarters. Orazio has kindly offered us a place to sleep for the night.
What have you done to yourself?
It's a shame seeing how your people treat themselves. If you resent your persecution, why then do you make of yourself such an easy target?
If you act as a loafer living off handouts, a societal leech, how can you rightfully expect a different result? You have so much potential and yet you squander it.
Get it out. Get it out, my friend.
It's all right, my boy. Get it out.
Who do you think you are? You think you're special? You think you float directly above everyone you encounter because you are beautiful? Because you are educated?
You're a tramp. Shh. You're a lady of the night.
You were in quite a state last night. Orazio carried you to bed!
It's a 4 hour train to the airport in Fiumicino so you have time for a rest. I hope your stomach isn't too sensitive on aeroplanes!
My dearest Zsofia! Mazel tov! She is so beautiful - your spitting image!
Don't be mad but your Uncle Laszlo insisted I enclose a few banknotes for you and Binyamin. We hope he won't be offended, and that it's not too difficult to change these into the local currency.
Here: I am so alone. Perhaps more alone than I have ever been. Your uncle has closed a door to me. The man I married is inside but the lock's combination, I cannot decipher...
He no longer attends synagogue. When I ask him why, he will not reply. Perhaps his own narcissism will no longer allow him a relationship with our community.
Tell me how you are. How you really are. All our love and warmth to the three of you. Erzsebet
Shame.
Yes. A terrible shame.
